params.text: Electronic Measurements with a Multimeter.(TestBoy TB313)

Although the measurement of simple physical parameters like time dates back to ancient times, measurement as a precise technology is only a few hundred years old. Accurate measurement is needed for economic design.
Here you can learn about the modern approach to measurement as well as applications and limitations of a multimeter.

To pass the course you must answer every question and click "Submit report" on the last page.

Objectives of Measurement

  1. To establish the validity of design.
  2. To predict the limit of capacity.
  3. To provide information needed to supplement further analytical work.

params.text: Measurements therminology

Measurand: The quantity to be measured is called measurand.

Transducer: A device that converts a physical quantity into an electrical quantity or vice-versa.

Signal conditioner: Amplification, Filtering, Modulation, Demodulation, A/D conversion, etc.

Significant figures: If the resistance value is specified as 68 Ω, its value is closer to 68 than 67 or 69. If the value is specified as 68.0 Ω, its value is closer to 68 than 68.1 or 67.9 Ω. Therefore, a zero after the decimal point is significant. When two or more measurements with different degrees of accuracy are added, the result is only as accurate as the least accurate measurement.

Error: The difference between the measured value and the true value is called error. Error is expressed specific to a particular measurement. Accuracy indicates the maximum error for a given instrument. The error in a particular reading will be less than or equal to the value given by accuracy.

Accuracy: Accuracy is the closeness with which an instrument reading approaches the true value of the variable being measured. Accuracy, in other words, indicates the maximum error, which will not be exceeded, as assured by the manufacturer of the instruments. If the accuracy of a 100 V voltmeter is ±1%, the maximum error for any reading will not exceed ±1 V.

Precision: Precision indicates the degree or level or number of decimal places to which a particular quantity can be measured. The difference between the two terms must be understood clearly. For example, π = 3.14 is a correct or true value. It can be mentioned as an accurate value. But π = 3.1428574 is a precise as well as an accurate value. However, if the π value is given as 3.2428574, it is still a precise value because the value is expressed to more number of decimal places, but it is not an accurate value. Thus, precision does not guarantee accuracy.

Expected value: It is the value of the parameter being measured or computed. To use the right kind of instrument and to select the correct range for measurement, one should know the correct value of the parameter being measured. For example, if voltage is being measured, whether the value is expected in μV, mV or tens of volts, hundreds of volts, etc; all require a specific instrument or settings to adequately measure.

params.text: Measurement Characteristics.

params.title: You can see the difference in resolution and number of significant values of two Freq. indicators

params.text:
Lag: If the input is changing rapidly, output must also change exactly at the same rate, in an ideal case. The time delay in the output to change with the input is termed as lag.

Sensitivity: The ratio of change in the output on the screen to the change in the input is called sensitivity. When Vi changes by 1 V and the output reading changes by 0.8 V only, the ratio is expressed as sensitivity.

Resolution: It is the smallest change the instrument can measure. For example, a 100 V voltmeter may not be able to measure 100 mV. Only when the minimum input is 0.5 V the reading may change from 0. Any input or change in input less than 0.5 V may have no effect on the instrument. Therefore, the resolution for that particular instrument is 0.5 V.

Repeatability: Assesses the variation in the readings of an instrument when it measures the same quantity multiple times under the same conditions and by the same operator, but with time gaps between measurements.

Reproducibility: For a given voltmeter, if 10V is applied as input, and the input is continuously connected to the instrument, the output reading of the voltmeter must be 10V. If it fluctuates, and reading changes, reproducibility of the instrument is poor.

Drift: There are three types of drifts.
1. Zero drift or calibration drift: The whole scale shifts by the same amount, 
2. Span drift: the drift is not constant, but increases gradually as the measurement indicator (like a pointer) moves further from the zero point.
3. Zone drift: the drift occurs only in a particular zone of the instrument.

Dead zone: Within this specific input range, the instrument does not detect or indicate any changes, rendering it unresponsive until the input exceeds the Dead zone.

Threshold: It is the minimum value to which the instrument responds when the input is gradually increased from zero value.

Limiting error or guarantee error: If a resistor value is given as 100 Ω ± 1 %, the manufacturer guarantees that the resistance value falls between the limits 99 and 101 Ω. The error is guaranteed to be no greater than the limits set.

Lag: If the input is changing rapidly, output must also change exactly at the same rate, in an ideal case. The time delay in the output to change with the input is termed as lag.
Types of errors

Gross Errors: These are basically human errors caused by the operator or person using the instrument. The different types of gross errors are:
(i) Taking wrong readings.
(ii) Reading with parallax error occurs when an observer's viewpoint is not directly aligned with the measurement markings, leading to an inaccurate reading.
(iii) Incorrect adjustments of zero and full-scale adjustments.
(iv) Improper applications of instruments: Using a 0–100 V voltmeter to measure voltages smaller than 0.1 V, etc.
(v) Wrong computation

Instrumental errors: Even if human errors are avoided or proper care is taken to see that such errors do not occur, errors can still occur in measurements due to the instrument. The possible reasons can be as follows:
(a) Friction in bearings of various moving components can cause incorrect readings.
(b) Irregular spring tension in analog meters.
(c) Calibration errors due to aging.
(d) Zero setting not adjusted properly.
(e) Full-scale setting not adjusted properly.
(f) Faulty display circuit in digital instruments.

Random Errors: Though gross errors and systematic errors can be avoided by taking proper care, some other errors can also occur in measurements. No specific reason can be assigned and precaution could be taken to avoid these errors
Multimeter Safety Notes

Proper and intended use:
This instrument is intended for use in applications described in the operation manual only. Any other usage is considered improper and non-approved usage and can result in accidents or the destruction of the instrument. Any misuse will result in the expiry of all guarantee and warranty claims on the part of the operator against the manufacturer.

Before you start working on a multimeter you have to make sure that:

  • The test leads and the measuring instrument is visually not damaged.
  • The equipments cables are visually not damaged.
  • Your hands and workspace are dry.
  • You recieved safety instructions of the laboratory and are familiar with the manufacturers manual for the equipment.
  • You are using appropriate power sources for the equipment.

And during you work:

  • You are following the safety instructions of the laboratory and of the manufacturer for the equipment.
  • You are using the equipment for its intended purpose.
  • Do NOT change the measurement mode while the test leads are plugged in.

In case of malfunctions (Eg. unusual noises, smoke, electrical shocks, etc.)

  • Switch off the equipment immedeately and inform the responsible specialist or supervisor.

  • Do not carry out any unauthorized repairs or maintenance work on the equipment. 

    Users are responsible for checking the equipment and machines in the lab with regards to safety before they use them.

  • The HSHL Lippstadt and all its entities do not guarantee that the systems fulfill the specific requirements of the users or that the systems run without failures or interruptions.

To familiarise oneself with the manufacturers manuals.

params.question: What must you do, while working on a multimeter, before changing the measurement mode?

params.text: Connecting the Multimeter to the circuit.

To understand how to connect a multimeter and get results we must remember what makes up a circuit:

1. Circuit elements - they moddify the current in some of many ways.
2. Nodes - we will think of them as wires that transfer the current to the elements without interacting with it. In between the nodes are circuit elements, which interupt it.
When an output of an element is connected to its input via same node, so that the current bypasses the element, is called a short circuit.

params.title: Also a node, since the element doesn`t do anything. (Is short circuited)

params.text:
Circuit elements can be connected:

  • In series - the output of the element is connected to the input of another one. The current is the same through all elements.

params.title: Two resistors are connected in series

metadata.title: Two resistors are connected in series

params.text: • Or in parallel - when the inputs of two or more elements are connected to the inputs via the same node and outputs are connected to the outputs. Among those elements the voltage stays the same.

Considering this, it makes sence, that when we want to find the voltage difference that the certain element creates, we will connect the multimeter in parallel to that element. (so the voltage on the multimeter would be the same)

When we use the multimeter as a voltmeter the resistance of a tool is very high, to prevent any current from going through it, so to have minimal effect on the circuit.

When measuring current (Amperes) you should connect the voltmeter in series with the measured element. 

By the same princible as before, the amperemeters resistance is very low, close to zero, to not interact with the current.

params.question: With which voltage frequency can you accurately and safely measure the voltage on TB 313?

params.text: Current measurements.

Use the selector switch to set the appropriate range. Connect the black test lead into the "COM" socket, and the red test lead with the mA / 10A socket (the appropriate socket opens automatically depending on the chosen range). Using the test probes, touch the test points of the test object. Read measurement value on the display. The current direction is indicated by the sign.

You must use the ’10 A’ socket when measuring currents above 200 mA!

To protect against overheating, when using the 10 A socket, measurements should not be taken for more than 10 seconds. Following this the device should be allowed to cool down for at least 15 minutes.

Postscript

Remember, at HSHL, students are required to:

  • Take responsibility for their own safety and health.
  • Consider the safety and health of others affected by their actions.

We highly recommend taking the time to familiarize yourself with any electrical or potentially dangerous equipment. You can do this by reading the manual or asking for help from someone with more experience. This will help you avoid unnecessary problems or injury.

Thank you for taking the time to go through the safety section and for helping to keep our labs safe and welcoming!
